#Text=CHAPTER VI .
#Text=What Happened to Andy

#Text=With the sun shining comfortably upon his back , and with a cigarette between his lips , Andy sat upon his horse and watched in silent glee while the irate Happy Family scurried here and there behind the band , swinging their ropes down upon the woolly backs , and searching their vocabularies for new and terrible epithets .
#Text=Andy smiled broadly as a colorful phrase now and then boomed across the coulee in that clear , snappy atmosphere , which carries sounds so far .
#Text=He did not expect to do much smiling upon his own account , that day , and he was therefore grateful for the opportunity to behold the spectacle before him .

#Text=There was Slim , for instance , unwillingly careening down hill toward home , because , in his zeal to slap an old ewe smartly with his rope , he drove her unexpectedly under his horse , and so created a momentary panic that came near standing both horse and rider upon their heads .

#Text=And there was Big Medicine whistling until he was purple , while the herder , with a single gesture , held the dog motionless , though a dozen sheep broke back from the band and climbed a slope so steep that Big Medicine was compelled to go after them afoot , and turn them with stones and profane objurgations .
#Text=It was very funny -- when one could sit at ease upon the hilltop and smoke a cigarette while others risked apoplexy and their souls ' salvation below .

#Text=By the time they panted up the last rock-strewn slope of the bluff , and sent the vanguard of the invaders under the fence , Andy 's mood was complacent in the extreme , and his smile offensively wide .
#Text=“ Oh , you need n't look so sorry for us , ” drawled the Native Son , jingling over toward him until only the fence and a few feet of space divided them .
#Text=“ Here 's where you get yours , amigo .
#Text=I wish you a pleasant day -- and a long one ! ”
#Text=He waved his hand in mocking adieu , touched his horse with his silver spurs , and rode gaily away down the coulee .
#Text=“ Here , sheepherder 's your outfit . Ma-aa-a-a ! ” jeered Big Medicine .
#Text=“ You 'll wisht , by cripes , you was a dozen men just like yuh before you 're through with the deal . Haw-haw-haw-w ! ”
#Text=There were others who , seeing Andy 's grin , had something to say upon the subject before they left .
#Text=Weary rode up , and looked undecidedly from Andy to the sheep , and back again .
#Text=“ If you do n't feel like tackling it single-handed , I 'll send -- ”
#Text=“ What do yuh think I am , anyway ? ”
#Text=Andy interrupted crisply , “ a Montgomery Ward two-for-a-quarter cowpuncher ?
#Text=Do n't you fellows waste any time worrying over me ! ”

#Text=The herders stared at Andy curiously when he swung in behind the tail-end of the band and kept pace with their slow moving , but they did not speak beyond shouting an occasional command to their dogs .
#Text=Neither did Andy have anything to say , until he saw that they were swinging steadily to the west , instead of keeping straight north , as they had been told to do .
#Text=Then he rode over to the nearest herder , who happened to be the bug-killer .
#Text=“ You do n't want to get turned around , ” he hinted quietly .
#Text=“ That 's north , over there . ”
#Text=“ I 'm workin ' fer the man that pays my wages , ” the fellow retorted glumly , and waved an arm to a collie that was waiting for orders .
#Text=The dog dropped his head , and ran around the right wing of the band , with sharp yelps and dartings here and there , turning them still more to the west .
#Text=Andy hesitated , decided to leave the man alone for the present , and rode around to the other herder .
#Text=“ You swing these sheep north ! ” he commanded , disdaining preface or explanation .
#Text=“ I 'm workin ' for the man that pays my wages , ” the herder made answer stolidly , and chewed steadily upon a quid of tobacco that had stained his lips unbecomingly .
#Text=So they had talked the thing over -- had those two herders -- and were following a premeditated plan of defiance !
#Text=Andy hooked at the man a minute .
#Text=“ You turn them sheep , damn you , ” he commanded again , and laid a hand upon his saddle-horn suggestively .
#Text=“ You go to the devil , damn yuh , ” advised the herder , and cocked a wary eye at him from under his hat-brim .

#Text=Not all herders , let it be said in passing , take unto themselves the mental attributes of their sheep ; there are those who believe that a bold front is better than weak compliance , and who will back that belief by a very bold front indeed .
#Text=Andy appraised him mentally , decided that he was an able-bodied man and therefore fightable , and threw his right leg over the cantle with a quite surprising alacrity .
#Text=“ Are you going to turn them sheep ? ”
#Text=Andy was taking off his coat when he made that inquiry .
#Text=“ Not for your tellin ' .
#Text=You keep back , young feller , or I 'll sick the dogs on yuh . ”
#Text=He turned and whistled to the nearest one , and Andy hit him on the ear .
#Text=They clinched and pummeled when they could and where they could .
#Text=The dog came up , circled the gyrating forms twice , then sat down upon his haunches at a safe distance , tilted his head sidewise and lifted his ears interestedly .
#Text=He was a wise little dog ; the other dog was also wise , and remained phlegmatically at his post , as did the bug-killer .
#Text=“ Are you going to turn them sheep ? ”
#Text=Andy spoke breathlessly , but with deadly significance .
